Situation1: Help each other in times of need or emotional distress.
Situation2: They attend a local workshop on updated prescription guidelines to ensure proper patient counseling.
Story: I glanced at my phone as I was getting ready to leave for the pharmacy workshop. A message from my sister popped up: “Can you come over? I really need to talk.” I knew she’d been having a rough week, and as her brother, I always tried to be there for her. Supporting each other was something we’d promised after our parents passed away. But tonight was also the only chance to attend the workshop on the new prescription guidelines—something my manager had stressed was crucial for our team. Missing it would mean falling behind, maybe even letting my patients down if I wasn’t up to date. My heart pounded as I stared at the clock, torn between the duty to my family and my responsibility as a pharmacist. I could hear my sister’s voice in my head, shaky and vulnerable, but I also pictured my patients, trusting me to give them the best advice. The weight of both roles pressed down on me, and I stood frozen, keys in hand, unable to move.
